captions.text:
Back home we call him
the miracle worker.

Indeed. May I offer you
something, gentlemen?

I might be able to offer
something to you.

I noticed you're still
working with polymers.

What else would I
be working with?

How thick would a piece
of your plexiglass

A way to manufacture
a wall
That would do the same job

Would that be worth
something to you, eh?

Perhaps the professor
could use your computer.

title: Star Trek 4: The Voyage Home (7/10) Movie CLIP - The Miracle Worker (1986) HD

comments.text:
Fun Fact: The Mac Scotty uses actually had an IBM processor for the scene, 
hence his ability to type data quickly without it crashing!﻿
comments.author: ForceMaximus84

comments.text:
Just to nitpick. Even if they revealed the secret of its composure what 
makes them certain there's the technology available in 1986 to manufacture 
it? If you showed a 2015 microprocessor to computer scientists in 1955 
they'd understand how it works and how it's designed. But manufacturing one 
in 1955?
Unless of course transparent aluminum was merely 5-10 years away from being 
discovered in the Star Trek timeline and the crew of the Enterprise just 
gave them a little help discovering it sooner. In this scenario it would 
have been well within their capability to manufacture the material.﻿
comments.author: Wez Marauder

comments.text: That must be space-typing too. Very impressive, indeed.﻿
comments.author: Anthony Honciano

comments.text:
Think about this. Why would the chief engineer of a starship from the 23rd 
century need to know how to type on a prehistoric keyboard from the 20th 
century? And don't try to tell me that he had an interest in ancient 
computers because if he did, then he would know better then to try to talk 
into a mouse! And how would he know how to input incredibly complex 
equations so quickly on a prehistoric computer even if he knew how to type? 
Even today 98% of drivers don't know how to drive stick shift. Why? Because 
they don't need to! So why does an engineer know how to type so well? I 
know, I'm just having fun. I love this movie but that always bugged me. 
That and the fact that a Bird of prey landed in a park and no one bumped 
into it or saw a helicopter lowering huge sheets of plexiglass into it.  ﻿

comments.author: Dean Holyer

comments.text:
All I can say Dean, is that maybe the man that Mr. Scott was talking to 
just needed a little nudging. Mr. Scott said, maybe he was the one that 
invented it". The movie might imply that in order to invent we need help 
from the future, but we know that the creation and imagination of Star 
Trek, has made inventors, engineers, and physicist work, to see if the 
ideas once thought about in Star Trek could actually come to fruition. 
Imagining the future creates a time where someone, somewhere will invent 
something that will be used at some point in the future! Whether they come 
from the future to teach our younger selves an innovative technology for 
transparent aluminum or a way to warp time and space. It's all just a 
matter of time!!

comments.text:
If +Tim O'Reilly 's Great Great Grandkids come back in time, they might 
encounter computers like this. (FF to 1m2sec)

You can see and hear Tim talk with +Slashdot about Voice UI and more in 
this 6-part video series:
http://news.slashdot.org/story/14/08/18/2349228/at-home-with-tim-oreilly-videos-1-and-2-of-6

"We've run a few two-part videos, but this is the first time we've split 
one video into six parts -- with two running today, two tomorrow, and two 
Thursday. But then, how many people do we interview who have had as much of 
an effect on the nature of information transmission -- as opposed to just 
publishing -- as Tim O'Reilly? We don't know for sure, but there's a good 
chance that O'Reilly books are owned by more Slashdot readers than books 
from any other publisher. That alone makes Tim O'Reilly worth listening to 
for nearly an hour, total."
Star Trek 4: The Voyage Home (7/10) Movie CLIP - The Miracle Worker (1986) 
HD

comments.author: zant burdine

comments.text:
I'll admit I'm biased toward the Sony product, but I really think the PS4 
is going to be the winning system this time around.

From a pure hardware/stat standpoint the two systems are functionally 
identical. Yes, there some differences in memory architecture, and the 
overall package included in the box differs slightly. Options on one are 
satandard on the other, blah blah blah. But 95% of the systems are the 
exact same. So let's say that the hardware is equal.

The PS4 is $100 cheaper. Even if you buy the (optional) camera, it's still 
$50 cheaper. Public reaction to the PS4 has been overwhelmingly and 
emphatically positive. People love it; they love the games; they love the 
social media tie-ins; and they love the quality of playstation plus.

Gamer reactions to the XBone have been that it is an improvement over the 
360 but maybe not a $500 improvement. The XBone appears to be a great way 
to watch TV with voice controls (throw away your remote). And the reviews 
of the voice controls have been either that it is the best thing since 
sliced bread, or that it doesn't work AT ALL. So even that isn't guaranteed.

If you're buying it for games, get a PS4. If you're buying it for 
hand's-free TV watching, wait a year for a non-gaming voice control box 
that actually works in 2014 for $150.
